profileText: A Representative from Kentucky; born near Versailles, Woodford County, Ky., January 15, 1794; pursued preparatory studies; was graduated from Yale College in 1815; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Frankfort in 1817; moved to Paris, Ky., in 1819; member of the State house of representatives in 1827 and 1828; elected as an Anti-Jacksonian to the Twenty-second and Twenty-third Congresses (March 4, 1831-March 3, 1835); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1834 to the Twenty-fourth Congress; judge of the State court of appeals 1835-1856; professor in the law department of Transylvania College, Lexington, Ky., 1836-1849; moved to Louisville in 1859; member of the State house of representatives in 1863; chief justice of the court of appeals in 1866 and 1867; died in Louisville, Ky., April 17, 1871; interment in Lexington Cemetery, Lexington, Ky.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Marshall, Thomas Alexander. An introductory address, delivered before the law class of Transylvania University of the 9th of Nov. 1839. Lexington, Ky.: Finnell & Virden, printers, 1839.

researchRecord.name: 1815-1871. ca. 20 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondence from and to Marshall relating to personal, business, and congressional matters, primarily in the Marshall family papers but also in miscellaneous papers and the James Taylor additional papers. Finding aid in repository. Restricted.
